title: Cody Pickett
text:
Cody J. Pickett (born June 30, 1980) is a former professional <a href="gridiron%20football">gridiron football</a> <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> and <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">Canadian Football League</a>. He was selected in the seventh round of the <a href="2004%20NFL%20Draft">2004 NFL Draft</a> by the <a href="2004%20San%20Francisco%2049ers%20season">San Francisco 49ers</a>, and played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at the <a href="Washington%20Huskies%20football">University of Washington</a> in <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a>.
Early years.
Born and raised in <a href="Caldwell%2C%20Idaho">Caldwell, Idaho</a>, Pickett was a four-sport athlete at <a href="Caldwell%20High%20School%20%28Caldwell%2C%20Idaho%29">Caldwell High School</a> and graduated in 1999. He lettered in <a href="American%20football">football</a>, <a href="basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="golf">golf</a>, and <a href="rodeo">rodeo</a>, in which he was a national champion. Originally recruited by <a href="Jim%20Lambright">Jim Lambright</a> at Washington, Pickett accepted a <a href="Athletic%20scholarship">scholarship</a> from new head coach <a href="Rick%20Neuheisel">Rick Neuheisel</a> to play for the Huskies.
Pickett's family home was located off Chicken Dinner Road, near Caldwell.
College career.
As a true freshman at Washington in <a href="1999%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">1999</a>, Pickett was the backup to starter <a href="Marques%20Tuiasosopo">Marques Tuiasosopo</a> and saw limited action; he was granted a <a href="Redshirt%20%28college%20sports%29">medical redshirt</a> for an ailing back in the last half of the season. He was the backup again to Tuiasosopo in <a href="2000%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">2000</a>; the Huskies went won the <a href="2001%20Rose%20Bowl">Rose Bowl</a> over <a href="2000%20Purdue%20Boilermakers%20football%20team">Purdue</a>, and finished third in the final polls.
Pickett was the starting quarterback at UW for three seasons from <a href="2001%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">2001</a>–<a href="2003%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">03</a>, where his primary target was <a href="wide%20receiver">wide receiver</a> <a href="Reggie%20Williams%20%28wide%20receiver%29">Reggie Williams</a>.
Rather than enter the <a href="2003%20NFL%20Draft">2003 NFL Draft</a> in the spring, Pickett chose to return to Washington for his senior season at age 23. His senior season saw a head coaching change, as Neuheisel was dismissed in the summer of 2003 and replaced with <a href="Keith%20Gilbertson">Keith Gilbertson</a>. He was considered a <a href="Heisman%20Trophy">Heisman Trophy</a> candidate and written up in "<a href="Sports%20Illustrated">Sports Illustrated</a>", but a shoulder injury that year hurt his chances.
Professional career.
Pickett was selected in the seventh round (217th overall) of the <a href="2004%20NFL%20Draft">2004 NFL Draft</a> by the <a href="San%20Francisco%2049ers">San Francisco 49ers</a>. Pickett started the <a href="2005%20NFL%20season">2005</a> season as the fourth-string <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a>, but became the starter after <a href="Tim%20Rattay">Tim Rattay</a> was traded, and <a href="Alex%20Smith">Alex Smith</a> and <a href="Ken%20Dorsey">Ken Dorsey</a> were injured. Pickett played on <a href="special%20teams">special teams</a> most of the season, an unusual role for a quarterback. He also played <a href="Safety%20%28American%20football%20position%29">safety</a> and <a href="wide%20receiver">wide receiver</a> during practice.
Pickett was traded on July 27, 2006 to the <a href="Houston%20Texans">Houston Texans</a> for a conditional draft pick in the <a href="2007%20NFL%20Draft">2007 NFL Draft</a>. He was released by the Texans on September 1, 2006. Pickett was selected to the 2007 <a href="Rhein%20Fire">Rhein Fire</a> <a href="NFL%20Europe">NFL Europe</a> team as a free agent and was their starting quarterback.
In July 2007, the <a href="Oakland%20Raiders">Oakland Raiders</a> signed Pickett to a one-year contract, but released him on August 1.
On September 18, 2007, Pickett was signed as a free agent by the <a href="Toronto%20Argonauts">Toronto Argonauts</a> of the <a href="Canadian%20Football%20League">CFL</a>. Pickett made his first CFL game appearance on September 12, 2008 against the visiting <a href="Winnipeg%20Blue%20Bombers">Winnipeg Blue Bombers</a> at <a href="Rogers%20Centre">Rogers Centre</a> in relief of starting quarterback <a href="Kerry%20Joseph">Kerry Joseph</a>. He made his first CFL start on September 20, 2008, against the <a href="Calgary%20Stampeders">Calgary Stampeders</a> at <a href="McMahon%20Stadium">McMahon Stadium</a>.
On August 11, 2009, head coach <a href="Bart%20Andrus">Bart Andrus</a> named Cody Pickett as the starting quarterback for the team's next game, against the <a href="B.C.%20Lions">B.C. Lions</a>.
On February 21, 2010, Pickett was released by the Argonauts. On March 8, 2010, Pickett was signed by the Montreal Alouettes. On June 7, 2010, Cody Pickett was released by the Montreal Alouettes. On June 15, 2010, Pickett was signed by the Calgary Stampeders.
Following the 2010 CFL season, Pickett retired from pro football and returned to Idaho.
NFL statistics.
"Source":
Personal life.
Pickett's father is Dee Pickett, a championship <a href="Cowboy">roper</a> on professional <a href="rodeo">rodeo</a> circuit and the <a href="1984%20in%20sports">1984</a> World Champion Cowboy, inducted into the <a href="ProRodeo%20Hall%20of%20Fame">ProRodeo Hall of Fame</a> in August 2003. Dee also played <a href="college%20football">college football</a>; a junior college transfer, he was the starting quarterback at <a href="Boise%20State%20Broncos%20football">Boise State</a> in <a href="1976%20Boise%20State%20Broncos%20football%20team">1976</a> and <a href="1977%20Boise%20State%20Broncos%20football%20team">1977</a>.
In the offseason, Pickett coached his younger sister's basketball team, Team 208, a travel team representing the Boise, Idaho area. He is the current head coach for the Eagle High School boys basketball team in Eagle, Idaho.
